div.p: Recommendation #3 (2022 CDC Clinical Practice Guideline for Prescribing Opioids for Pain):

p.strong: When starting opioid therapy for acute, subacute, or chronic pain, clinicians should prescribe immediate-release opioids instead of extended-release and long-acting (ER/LA) opioids (recommendation category: A; evidence type: 4).

details.p: The following artifacts formalize the description of the logic and behavior defined by this recommendation.

tr.td: Patient is 18 years or older and has a Medication Request authored "Today" for 12 HR Oxycodone Hydrochloride 10 MG Extended Release Oral Tablet which is an "Extended Release Opioid with Ambulatory Abuse Potential". This will result in a recommendation message: "Recommend use of immediate-release opioids instead of extended release/long acting opioids when starting patient on opioids."

Patient is 18 years or older and has a Medication Request authored "Today" for Buprenorphine 2 MG / Naloxone 0.5 MG Oral Strip which is not an "Extended Release Opioid". This will not result in any recommendation messages.

Patient is 18 years or older and has a Medication Request authored "Today" for Buprenorphine 2 MG / Naloxone 0.5 MG Oral Strip which is not an "Extended Release Opioid". Additionally, the patient has an active Medication Request for 12 HR Oxycodone Hydrochloride 10 MG Extended Release Oral Tablet which is an "Extended Release Opioid with Ambulatory Abuse Potential". This will not result in any recommendation messages.
